Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of Cat-1 and Cat-2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TG-DTA curves of the catalysts in nitrogen flow: (a, A) H3PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41, (b, B) Cat-2(uncalcined), and (c, C) Cat-1(uncalcined). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 31P MAS NMR spectra of Cat-1 and Cat-2. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) Low-angle XRD profiles of MCM-41, Zr-MCM-41, Cat-1 and Cat-2; (B) High-angle XRD profiles of H3PW12O40, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, Cat-1 and Cat-2. Graphical abstract Under the optimized reaction conditions: 315 °C, GHSV of 4 h−1, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loading of 50 wt%, aqueous glycerol concentration of 10 wt%, the Cat-1 (Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst prepared by the supercritical impregnation) showed higher glycerol conversion, acrolein selectivity and stability than those of the Cat-2 (Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst prepared by conventional wet impregnation). The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 samples were synthesized by supercritical impregnation and investigated in gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 sample prepared by conventional wet impregnation was also examined for comparison. The catalysts were studied using X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption, the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia, infrared spectroscopy after pyridine adsorption, thermogravimetric analysis, 31P MAS NMR, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry and CHNS analysis. According to the results of characterization, the preparation condition of supercritical carbon dioxide facilitated the improvement of the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 dispersion on Zr-MCM-41. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were increased, and the total amount of surface acid sites and the ratio of Brønsted acid sites to total acidity were increased. The strong acid sites were transformed into the weak and medium acid sites. The formation of coke was retarded. Therefore, the glycerol conversion, acrolein selectivity and yield, and the catalytic stability were obviously improved. Keywords Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 Supercritical impregnation Glycerol Dehydration Acrolein 1 Introduction Nowadays, the conversion of biomass feedstocks into high value-added products is a significant trend of modern chemical industry. Biodiesel is one of the most important products. As the rapid development of biodiesel, a great amount of byproduct glycerol is generated [1]. Therefore, it is imperative to transform glycerol into valuable chemicals, such as dehydration to acrolein [2–5], hydrogenation to 1,2-propanediol [6,7], reforming to hydrogen [8,9] and oxidation to glyceric acid [10]. Among them, the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein has gained much attention since it is a substitutable way to produce acrolein from petroleum-based propylene. Acrolein is a versatile intermediate applied as feedstock in numerous aspects, such as the manufacture of adhesive, detergents, polymers, and acrylic acid esters [11]. Up to now, the dehydration of glycerol has been studied in gas, liquid, subcritical and supercritical conditions [2–5]. Due to the environmental and technical problems, the dehydration of glycerol is mainly conducted by gas phase on some solid acid catalysts. Sulfates [2], phosphoric metals [12], metal oxides [13] and zeolites [2,3] have been studied. However, the main disadvantage of these catalysts is severe carbon deposit, which greatly reduced the catalytic performance. Heteropolyacids with stable Keggin structures have been widely researched due to its rich Brønsted acid sites and adjustable acidity [14–16]. However, heteropolyacids have many disadvantages, such as poor specific surface area and easy leaching in polar solvents [17]. Therefore, several acidic or neutral supports have been employed for heteropolyacids, including alumina, active carbon, silica, titania and zirconia [18]. Owing to the particular properties, such as large specific surface area and pore size, high thermal stability, mesopore material MCM-41 has attracted considerable research interest since its potential application in catalytic conversion of organic large molecules [19]. However, the pure MCM-41 has very weak acidity, which can be enhanced by introducing some elements. For instance, García-Sancho et al. [20] investigated a series of Zr-MCM-41 samples during glycerol dehydration. They found that the addition of Zr can facilitate the increase in the acidity of MCM-41, and the Zr-MCM-41 exhibited excellent catalytic activity. Another effective way to improve the heteropolyacids performance is to partially exchange protons of the heteropolyacids with alkali metals, which was insoluble in water and showed a relatively high specific surface area (>100 m2/g) [21]. For example, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 is difficult to be dissolved by water, and it has strong Brønsted acid and high thermal stability [22]. Alhanash et al. [23] researched the catalytic performance of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, which exhibited high acrolein selectivity and glycerol conversion, but it was deactivated rapidly due to excessive coke formation. Liu et al. [24] reported that Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Nb2O5 catalysts showed high stability, but the gas flow rate was so low. Supercritical fluids have been extensively applied in the synthesis of materials because of their high diffusibility, low viscosity and surface tension. Among the supercritical fluids, supercritical carbon dioxide is widely applied, because it’s abundant, uninflammable and unreactable [25]. Furthermore, the supercritical point of carbon dioxide (Tc = 31.1 °C, Pc = 7.38 MPa) is relatively low. Therefore, carbon dioxide can be completely removed from materials. Zhao et al. [25] reported the synthesis of Ru/MOF nanocomposites using RuCl3·3H2O as precursor in supercritical carbon dioxide-methanol solution. The as-synthesized catalysts showed very high catalytic activities in the hydrogenation of cyclohexene and benzene. In order to obtain a high dispersion of palladium nanoparticles on the surface of graphene oxide, Tang et al. [26] used hydrogen as a reducing agent in supercritical carbon dioxide, and the catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the Suzuki reaction even after 10 cycles. Therefore, in this study, we have researched the catalytic performance of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 (Cat-1) during the gas phase dehydration of glycerol for the first time, which was prepared by supercritical impregnation method under supercritical carbon dioxide atmosphere. For comparison, the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 (Cat-2) catalyst synthesized by conventional impregnation method was also examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The MCM-41 and Zr-MCM-41 (the molar ratio of Si/Zr = 15) materials were synthesized according to our previous report [27]. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was prepared by the method described in the literatures [23,24]. The H3PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method. 40 mL of deionized water was placed in a 100 mL beaker, then 1.5 g of Zr-MCM-41 and 1.346 g of H3PW12O40 were added into the beaker under vigorous stirring for 4 h at room temperature. The mixture was kept still in the beaker for 12 h at room temperature and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/MCM-41 (C-1) catalyst was synthesized by the supercritical impregnation method: 0.196 g of Cs2CO3, 1.346 g of H3PW12O40, 1.5 g of MCM-41 and 40 mL of deionized water were placed in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave. The reactor was pressurized with carbon dioxide to 10 MPa at 80 °C under stirring and maintained under these conditions for 4 h. Then the reactor was cooled to room temperature and carbon dioxide was released, and the mixture in the autoclave was poured into a 100 mL crucible and kept still for 12 h at room temperature and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the sample in the crucible was cooled to room temperature and calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/MCM-41 (C-2) catalyst was synthesized by the conventional wet impregnation method: 40 mL of deionized water was placed in a 100 mL beaker, and 0.196 g of Cs2CO3, 1.346 g of H3PW12O40 and 1.5 g of MCM-41 were added into the beaker under vigorous stirring for 4 h at 80 °C. Then the mixture was kept still in the beaker for 12 h at room temperature and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The sample in the beaker was cooled to room temperature and poured into a 100 mL crucible. Finally, the sample in the crucible was calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The Cat-1 was synthesized by the supercritical impregnation method: 0.196 g of Cs2CO3, 1.346 g of H3PW12O40, 1.5 g of Zr-MCM-41 and 40 mL of deionized water were placed in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave. The reactor was pressurized with carbon dioxide to 10 MPa at 80 °C under stirring and maintained under these conditions for 4 h. Then the reactor was cooled to room temperature and carbon dioxide was released, and the mixture in the autoclave was poured into a 100 mL crucible and kept still for 12 h at room temperature and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the sample in the crucible was cooled to room temperature and calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. For comparison, the Cat-2 was also synthesized by the conventional wet impregnation method: 40 mL of deionized water was placed in a 100 mL beaker, 0.196 g of Cs2CO3, 1.346 g of H3PW12O40 and 1.5 g of Zr-MCM-41 were added into the beaker under vigorous stirring for 4 h at 80 °C. Then the mixture was kept still in the beaker for 12 h at room temperature and dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The sample in the beaker was cooled to room temperature and poured into a 100 mL crucible. Finally, the sample in the crucible was calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 using Cu Kα radiation. N2 adsorption–desorption experiments were performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. In order to characterize the acidity properties of the samples, the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a XianQuan TP-5076. 0.1 g of catalyst was pretreated in He (40 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h, and the sample was treated with ammonia after cooling down to 100 °C. Then, the catalyst was purged with He. Finally, NH3-TPD experiments were conducted in He from 30 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) after pyridine adsorption experiments were performed using a Shimadzu FTIR-8700 spectrometer. The amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were determined from the intensities of the IR bands at 1540 and 1445 cm−1 for adsorbed pyridine using Emeis’ method [28]. The equations are as follows: C(pyridine on B sites) = 1.88 IA(B) R2/W; C(pyridine on L sites) = 1.42 IA(L) R2/W; C = concentration (mmol/g catalyst); IA(B, L) = integrated absorbance of B or L band (cm−1); R = radius of catalyst disk (cm); W = weight of disk (mg). FTIR spectra of the samples were performed on a Nexus 670 IR spectrometer in the range of 1200–600 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was measured in a Netzsch STA 449C instrument. The catalysts were loaded in an Al2O3 crucible, and heated in N2 (50 mL/min) at a heating rate of 20 °C/min from 25 to 900 °C. The 31P MAS NMR were taken on a Varian 7.05 T-Mercury Plus, operating at 121.4 MHz at 25 °C. The sample was loaded into 7 mm silicon nitride rotor, which was filled and packed inside a dry box with dry nitrogen. The conditions included a single pulse excitation with 8.0 μs duration, an acquisition time of 0.25 ms and a recycle delay of 10 s, without 1H decoupling. The MAS rate was 5 kHz and 512 acquisitions were recorded. Signals were indirectly referenced to 85 wt% H3PO4 (δ = 0 ppm). W elemental content analysis was analyzed by means of inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), which was taken on a PerkinElmer Optima 7300 DV. The carbon content in the spent catalysts was analyzed for elemental analysis by using a CHNS analyzer (Vario EL III). 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic activity was evaluated at atmospheric pressure in a vertical fixed-bed reactor (25 cm length, 8 mm i.d.) using 0.5 g of catalyst. The catalyst was ground and sieved to sizes between 20 and 40 mesh and placed in the middle part of the reactor, with quartz particles packed at both ends. The reaction temperature was monitored by a thermocouple which was placed near the catalyst bed. N2 gas was used as a carrier gas to ensure that the reactants and products formed were transported more efficiently and collected. Before reaction, the samples were pretreated under reaction temperature and nitrogen flow (40 mL/min) for about 1 h to remove adsorbed water. The aqueous glycerol solution (10 wt%, 0.07 mL/min) was firstly introduced into a vaporizer by a HPLC pump, then it was introduced from the top of the reactor at a certain feed rate in a N2 flow (10 mL/min). The reaction products were collected in a conical flask cooled in a water-ice mixture after 1 h of reaction and collected hourly for analysis. The products were analyzed by a SP 6890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HP-INNOWAX capillary column(60 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) using methanol as internal standard. Glycerol conversion and product selectivity were quantified as follows: Glycerol conversion (%) = (Moles of glycerol reacted/Moles of glycerol in the feed) × 100 Product selectivity (%) = (Moles of carbon in a product formed/Moles of carbon in glycerol consumed) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The FT-IR spectra of Cat-1 and Cat-2 catalysts are shown in Fig.1 . The band at about 1080 cm−1 was due to the stretching frequency of PO in the central PO4 tetrahedron, the band at about 983 cm−1 was assigned to terminal WO in the exterior WO6 octahedron, and the bands at about 889 and 803 cm−1 corresponded to the WOW bridges [29]. The characteristic bands at about 1080, 983, 889, and 803 cm−1 were appeared on the Cat-1 and Cat-2 catalysts, indicating that the Keggin structure in the Cat-1 and Cat-2 catalysts was intact during the process of catalyst preparation. The thermal stability of H3PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41, Cat-1 (uncalcined) and Cat-2 (uncalcined) catalysts was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under nitrogen flow (Fig. 2 ). For H3PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41, the DTA curve showed a weak endothermic peak at about 100 °C, which was attributed to the water loss. The strong exothermic peak at about 480 °C was attributed to the decomposition of the Keggin structure of H3PW12O40 [30]. For Cat-2 (uncalcined), there was no decomposition up to 700 °C, suggesting that Cs+ contributed to enhance the catalyst thermal stability. For Cat-1 (uncalcined), there was no decomposition up to 800 °C. Cat-1 showed higher thermal stability than Cat-2. In our work, the calcination temperature of Cat-1 and Cat-2 was 500 °C, therefore, the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phases on the Cat-1 and Cat-2 were impossible to be decomposed. In order to prove whether or not the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase was decomposed during the calcination process, we characterized the Cat-1 and Cat-2 catalysts by 31P MAS NMR, and the result is shown in Fig. 3 . According to the results of references [31], the characteristic peaks of the calculated Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase were at −14.3 and −12.9 ppm in the 31P MAS NMR spectrum. In the 31P MAS NMR spectrum of Cat-2, two corresponding characteristic peaks shifted left to -14.2 and -12.8 ppm, respectively. We speculated that the key reason may be the interaction between Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 and Zr-MCM-41. In the 31P MAS NMR spectrum of Cat-1, two corresponding characteristic peaks shifted left to −14.0 and −12.5 ppm, and the spectra were broadened, indicating that the interaction of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 and Zr-MCM-41 became stronger than that of Cat-2, because the supercritical impregnation process could improve the dispersity of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 on the Cat-1, and the high dispersity could increase the amount of sites at which the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase acted with the Zr-MCM-41. Actually, we couldn’t judge whether the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase was insoluble in supercritical carbon dioxide or not during our work, because the experiment was carried out in a stainless steel autoclave, and we couldn't observe what's happening in the reactor. At the end of experiment, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and carbon dioxide was released, then we took out the sample from the reactor. The starting point of our work was that we used the supercritical carbon dioxide to increase the fluidity, diffusion and dispersity of Cs2CO3 and H3PW12O40 on the surface or in the pore channel of support, and the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase would be produced on the surface or in the pore channel of support by the direct interaction between Cs2CO3 and H3PW12O40 phases, so as to achieve the purpose of increasing the dispersity of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase on the support. Of course, it's better for the increase of the dispersity if the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase was soluble in supercritical carbon dioxide. Fig. 4 A represented the low-angle XRD profiles of the samples. The patterns consisted of a very strong peak along with two weak peaks for all samples, which accords with a well ordered hexagonal mesopore structure [32]. However, when the certain amount of zirconium and Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 were incorporated, intensities of the corresponding peaks were weaker than that of the bare support, and the main peak of Cat-1 was slightly stronger than that of Cat-2. The results confirm that the mesopore structure of the catalysts was almost unchanged and a sharp decrease of the long-range order happened. The high-angle XRD profiles of H3PW12O40, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, Cat-1 and Cat-2 samples were illustrated in Fig. 4B. For H3PW12O40, many intense characteristic diffraction peaks particularly at about 20, 26.7 and 29.6° were clearly found between 2θ = 10 and 90° [27]. Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 shows some obvious peaks at 2θ = 11.0°, 17.4°, 20.2°, 26.8° and 30.3°, which were consistent with earlier results [23,24]. For Cat-2, some peaks of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 were obvious. For Cat-1, there was only a broad peak in the range of 2θ = 15–40° corresponding to an amorphous phase of SiO2 observed without the corresponding peaks of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40, suggesting that the dispersity of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was higher under the preparation condition in supercritical carbon dioxide. This may be due to that supercritical fluids have the advantage of high diffusivity, which causes the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 disperse uniformly on the surface of Zr-MCM-41. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of N2 and mesopore size distributions of the samples are shown in Fig. 5 (A) and (B), respectively. In Fig. 5(A), all the samples showed a type IV isotherm, which was characteristic for mesopore MCM-41 structure [32]. In Fig. 5(B), the pore size distribution curves exhibited that the pore size of all the samples was more than 2 nm, which was the typical mesopore structure. However, the type IV isotherm was weaker and weaker, and the pore size became smaller and smaller in the order of MCM-41, Zr-MCM-41, Cat-1 and Cat-2. The reason was the loading of zirconium and Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 on the internal surface of mesopore, and the dispersity of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was enhanced under the supercritical carbon dioxide. Therefore, the mesopore size of Cat-1 was larger than that of Cat-2. The textural properties of catalysts are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen that the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the Zr-MCM-41 were lower than those of bare MCM-41 because of the addition of zirconium, and these parameters were further decreased by impregnation of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 into the mesopore of Zr-MCM-41. In addition, these parameters of Cat-1 and C-1 were larger than those of Cat-2 and C-2. It may be due to that supercritical fluids had the advantage of high diffusivity, which facilitated the entrance of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 into the mesopore and its dispersion on the internal surface, and the agglomerated or superposed tendency of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 particals was suppressed. The NH3-TPD experiment was carried to characterize the acidic properties of the samples, and we deconvoluted the NH3-TPD curves, the results were shown in Fig. 6 and Table 1. The acid strength is usually determined by the temperature of the ammonia desorption: weak (100–200 °C), medium (200–400 °C) and strong (>400 °C) [33]. In our work, no peak was found for the MCM-41 by NH3-TPD, which was in agreement with the results reported by the research team led by Zheng [34–38] and Sancho et al. [20], indicating that the pure MCM-41 did not have obvious acid sites. It was obvious that Zr-MCM-41 exhibits two peaks at 193 and 230 °C, which revealed the presence of weak and medium acid sites on the Zr-MCM-41. There were three obvious peaks at 198, 302 and 450 °C, which proved that there were weak, medium and strong acid sites on the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40. The amount of weak and medium acid sites on Cat-1 were larger than those of Cat-2, whereas the amount of the strong acid site of Cat-1 was smaller than that of Cat-2. Finally, the total amount of acid sites of Cat-1 was more than that of Cat-2. The temperatures of NH3-TPD on Cat-1 were lower than those of Cat-2, indicating the acid strength of Cat-1 was weaker than that of Cat-2. The key reason was maybe the high dispersion of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 under the Cat-1 preparation condition of supercritical carbon dioxide. The total amount of acid sites of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/MCM-41 was less than that of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalysts, because the acidity of MCM-41 was weaker than that of Zr-MCM-41. For C-1 and C-2, the changes in the acidic properties were similar to those for Cat-1 and Cat-2. Fig. 7 exhibits the FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorption of the catalysts. The peak at around 1445 cm−1 was attributed to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites. The peak at 1490 cm−1 was assigned to both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and the absorption band at around 1540 cm−1 was due to Brønsted acid sites [39]. The amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were shown in Table 1. According to references [39–41], it is well-known that pure MCM-41 is a solid acid with only Lewis acid sites. In our work, the Brønsted acid sites were also not detected on the MCM-41. The Brønsted acid sites of Zr-MCM-41 were attributed to Zr atoms replacing the Si atoms, which were related to the changes in electron density on Si. Owing to the charge imbalance in electronegativity, Zr atom was introduced in the vicinity of the hydroxyl carrying silicon, which weakened the Si−OH bond and generated Brønsted acid sites [20,27]. The amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were obviously increased by the loading of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 on the Cat-1 and Cat-2. Meanwhile, the ratio of B/(L + B) was increased. The Cat-1 exhibited more Brønsted and less Lewis acid sites than those of Cat-2, and the ratio of B/(L + B) on Cat-1 was larger than that of Cat-2, because the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was highly dispersed on the Cat-1 under the supercritical carbon dioxide atmosphere and it was a very strong Brønsted acid [22]. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/MCM-41 catalysts exhibited more Lewis and less Brønsted acid sites than those of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41, and the ratio of B/(L + B) on Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/MCM-41 was lower than that of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41, because the MCM-41 is a solid acid with only Lewis acid sites. For C-1 and C-2, the changes in the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were similar to those for Cat-1 and Cat-2. 3.2 Catalytic performance According to the results in Table 2 , the glycerol conversion and the acrolein selectivity on the Zr-MCM-41 were higher than those of MCM-41, however, the hydroxyacetone selectivity on the Zr-MCM-41 was lower than that of MCM-41, because the addition of Zr resulted in producing a certain amount of Brønsted acid sites on the Zr-MCM-41 surface. The Brønsted acid sites facilitated the acrolein formation during the glycerol dehydration. The deactivation rate for Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was fastest, because its specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were smallest and it had most strong acid sites, which would result in the formation of coke, the pore and active sites would be covered by the coke. The catalytic stability and the acrolein selectivity on C-1 were higher than those of C-2, however, the hydroxyacetone selectivity on C-2 was higher than that of C-1. According to the results of NH3-TPD and pyridine-FTIR, the supercritical impregnation conditions resulted in increasing of the amount of weak, medium and Brønsted acid sites. Simultaneously, the amount of strong and Lewis acid sites decreased. Finally, the total acidity was increased under the supercritical impregnation conditions. The higher glycerol conversion may be caused by the more acidity, and the more strong acid sites may cause more coke formation. For Cat-1 and Cat-2, the regularity of the products distribution was similar to that for C-1 and C-2. By comparing the catalytic performance between Cat-1 and C-1 (or Cat-2 and C-2), the acrolein selectivity on Cat-1 (or Cat-2) was higher than that of C-1 (or C-2), however, the hydroxyacetone selectivity on Cat-2 (or Cat-1) was lower than that of C-2 (or C-1), because the addition of Zr resulted in increasing the amount of Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface and the ratio of B/(B + L). In order to research the effect of supercritical preparation method on the catalytic performance of catalysts, we compared the Cat-1 and Cat-2 under the same reaction conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The glycerol conversion and the acrolein selectivity on Cat-1 were higher than those of Cat-2. After 50 h reaction time, the glycerol conversion decreased from 100% to 82% on the Cat-1, however, the glycerol conversion decreased from 100% to 55% on the Cat-2. The stability of Cat-1 was obviously higher than that of Cat-2. The selectivity to all by-products over Cat-1 and Cat-2 are shown in Fig. 9 . Among them, hydroxyacetone was the main by-product. According the proposed reaction pathways for gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein [30], the Brønsted acid sites were beneficial to produce acrolein, allyl alcohol and acrylic acid, and the Lewis acid sites easily led to the formation of hydroxyacetone, acetaldehyde and acetic acid. According to the results in Table 1, the Cat-1 exhibited more Brønsted and less Lewis acid sites than those of Cat-2, and the ratio of B/(L + B) on Cat-1 was larger than that of Cat-2. Therefore, as the reaction time increasing, the selectivity of hydroxyacetone became higher and higher on the same catalyst, and the selectivity of hydroxyacetone on Cat-1 was lower than that of Cat-2 at the same reaction time. The coke amounts of the catalyst used for 50 h were measured on a CHNS analyzer, and the W elemental content of the fresh catalyst and catalyst used for 50 h were analyzed by means of ICP-AES. The results were shown in Table 3 . After 50 h, the leaching ratio was very low on two kinds of catalysts, especially on the Cat-1, because the high dispersity increased the amount of sites at which the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase acted with the Zr-MCM-41, the amount of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase that interacted with the Zr-MCM-41 increased, and the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase that acted with the Zr-MCM-41 was difficult to be leached. The coke amounts of Cat-2 was larger than that of Cat-1. According to the results in Table 1, the amount of total acidity and Brønsted acid sites on Cat-1 were more than those of Cat-2, because the dispersity of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was enhanced under the preparation condition in supercritical carbon dioxide. The Brønsted acid sites were beneficial to produce acrolein [42]. And the larger specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of the Cat-1 catalyst would reduce the constraints to the mass transfer and improve the performance by facilitating both the access of the reactants to the active sites and the diffusion of reaction products. Therefore, the glycerol conversion and acrolein selectivity were obviously enhanced on the Cat-1. Compared with Cat-2, the amount of strong acid sites decreased and the amount of weak and medium acid sites increased on the Cat-1. The strong acid sites easily caused the formation of the coke, and the weak and medium acid sites were helpful for the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. Therefore, the amount of coke on Cat-1 was obviously less than that of Cat-2, and the stability of Cat-1 was obviously higher than that of Cat-2. 3.3 Regeneration of used Cat-1 Catalyst regeneration is an important issue in the glycerol dehydration reaction. After 50 h reaction time, the used Cat-1 catalyst was heated to 450 °C in air for 3 h. The catalytic results are presented in Fig. 10 . For the regenerated Cat-1, it was obvious that the catalytic performance was nearly fully recovered by burning the carbon deposition over the used catalyst. However, the glycerol conversion and acrolein selectivity were slightly lower than those of the fresh catalyst because of the active phase leaching. The results indicated that the Cat-1 catalyst was regenerated under the regeneration conditions and exhibited excellent reusability in the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. 3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions 3.4.1 The loading of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase Fig. 11 exhibits the catalytic behavior of Cat-1 with different Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loadings. The glycerol conversion and acrolein yield gradually increased as adding the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loading from 5 wt% to 35 wt%, and the acrolein selectivity nearly remained unchanged. Then, the conversion, selectivity and yield almost kept the same between 35 wt% and 50 wt% of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loadings. However, the conversion, selectivity and yield began to decrease with increasing of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loadings more than 50 wt%. As increasing the loading of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase, the acidity of Cat-1 gradually increased, therefore, the catalytic performance became better and better. When the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loading was more than 50 wt%, excess Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 phase would agglomerate or superpose in the mesopore channels, which would result in the decrease of the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size, and hyperacidity would cause the formation of coke. Therefore, the catalytic performance began to become weaker and weaker. In our work, we chose the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 loading of 50 wt%. 3.4.2 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Cat-1 is shown in Fig. 12 . The high reaction temperature is helpful to improve the glycerol conversion, because the dehydration of glycerol is a kind of endothermic reaction. Therefore, the glycerol conversion was gradually improved as increasing the reaction temperature. After 315 °C, the trend of increasing conversion slowed down as increasing the reaction temperature, and the acrolein selectivity began to become lower and lower because of the coke and other by-products formation under higher temperature. Finally, the yield of acrolein began to decrease after 315 °C reaction temperature. 3.4.3 Effect of GHSV The effect of GHSV on the catalytic performance over Cat-1 was shown in Fig. 13 . From the results, it could be clearly seen that the GHSV had a significant impact on the catalytic performance. As increasing of GHSV from 1 to 10 h−1, the glycerol conversion gradually decreased, and the acrolein selectivity gradually increased, simultaneously. The reason for the decrease of glycerol conversion may be that the higher space velocity shortened the residence time of glycerol on the catalyst. The reason for the increase of acrolein selectivity may be that the higher space velocity reduced the probability of acrolein reacting with unreacted glycerol, and the selectivity of by-products was decreased [30]. The highest yield of acrolein appeared at the GHSV of 4 h−1 in our work. 3.4.4 Optimization of aqueous glycerol concentration The catalytic results under different aqueous glycerol concentrations over Cat-1 are given in Fig. 14 . It was observed that the Cat-1 catalyst with 10 wt% aqueous glycerol concentration got the highest glycerol conversion and acrolein yield. There was the competitive adsorption between water and glycerol on the acid sites. When the aqueous glycerol concentration was lower than 10 wt%, large amounts of water would block the acid sites from being accessible for reactants [43]. Therefore, the glycerol conversion was low. As increasing the aqueous glycerol concentration, more and more constraints to the mass transfer were caused during the reaction, so the glycerol conversion became lower and lower. Meanwhile, the acrolein would react with the increasing glycerol, therefore, the acrolein selectivity gradually decreased. 4 Conclusions In this work, we prepared Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst by supercritical impregnation for the first time and compared the catalytic behavior with Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst by conventional wet impregnation in the gas phase dehydration of glycerol. The preparation in supercritical carbon dioxide improved the dispersion of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 on the surface of catalyst. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were increased, and the total acidity and the ratio of B/(B + L) were increased. The strong acid sites were transformed into the weak and medium acid sites. Therefore, the formation of coke was retarded, and the glycerol conversion, acrolein selectivity and yield were improved, and the catalyst lifetime was obviously prolonged. The leaching ratio of Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was very low, because the interaction between Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 and Zr-MCM-41 was enhanced, and the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 was difficult to be leached. Therefore, the key reason of catalyst deactivation was the coke formation. The results of regeneration proved that the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalyst prepared by supercritical impregnation exhibited excellent reusability in the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. coredata.dc:description: The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 samples were synthesized by supercritical impregnation and investigated in gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. The Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 sample prepared by conventional wet impregnation was also examined for comparison. The catalysts were studied using X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption, the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia, infrared spectroscopy after pyridine adsorption, thermogravimetric analysis, 31P MAS NMR, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry and CHNS analysis. According to the results of characterization, the preparation condition of supercritical carbon dioxide facilitated the improvement of the Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 dispersion on Zr-MCM-41. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were increased, and the total amount of surface acid sites and the ratio of Brønsted acid sites to total acidity were increased. The strong acid sites were transformed into the weak and medium acid sites. The formation of coke was retarded. Therefore, the glycerol conversion, acrolein selectivity and yield, and the catalytic stability were obviously improved.
coredata.dc:title: Gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein over Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40/Zr-MCM-41 catalysts prepared by supercritical impregnation
